awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Questions in Hyperbolic Balance Laws
awd_abstract_narration:
Hyperbolic balance laws are important nonlinear systems of equations utilized in the description of the motion of fluids, gases, plasma, and waves. This project focuses on several fundamental and challenging questions concerning the validity and effectiveness of different fluid flow models, the dynamical stability of fluids and the behavior of large amplitude solutions, and the modeling of strong waves in one or multiple spatial dimensions, which often appear in realistic situations. This research aims to provide fresh insights and develop new tools to characterize complicated but interesting behavior driven by nonlinearity and resonances. Increased understanding of the behavior of solutions to these modeling equations will find important applications to the dynamics of compressible fluids, the mechanics of elastic materials, traffic control systems, porous medium flows, and geophysical dynamics. The project also involves international collaborations and training of graduate students and young researchers in this challenging field.

This research project focuses on four goals: (1) To provide a clear picture of the global existence and finite-time blow-up for compressible Euler equations in one dimension with large initial data, and to find sharp density lower bound estimates for generic large solutions; (2) To establish a reasonable justification of the isentropic approximation in compressible fluids when initial entropy tends to a constant, for both inviscid and viscous fluids; (3) To investigate nonlinear Rayleigh-Taylor type instabilities in compressible fluids, including the compressible Navier-Stokes-Fourier system; (4) To study the large-time asymptotic behavior of compressible full Euler equations with frictional damping in three dimensions to justify Darcy's law, and to undertake the modeling and analysis of interactions between short waves and long waves in compressible fluids under the influence of magnetic fields. These research activities aim to provide a solid mathematical foundation to bridge gaps between existing results and for future studies.  It is anticipated that the results will significantly advance basic understanding of nonlinear hyperbolic balance laws.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Motion of many disturbances (referred as waves) in the air, liquid and many other materials, is described by systems of nonlinear equations, that consists of some fundamental balance laws from physics. This project is devoted to the mathematical study of Navier-Stokes Equations, Euler equations, and Magneto-hydrodynamics equations. Similar equations provide mathematical models for phenomena in related scientific areas, including porous medium flows, and geophysical dynamics. To determine the validity of a particular equation as a model for given phenomenon, it can be helpful to determine whether the equation has a solution, and if it does, how  this solution depends upon the physical parameters, and how accurate it models the real world phenomena. If in particular regimes, these equations either lack solutions, or have solutions that carry big error from obeservations in real world, this will indicate that these mathematical descriptions of phenomena have only limited validity for the particular applications. This project will focus on several fundamental challenging problems for large solutions modeling strong waves,  singular behaviors across edges of different regimes, and instability in the fluids, which often appear in realistic situations. The research will bring fresh insights and develop new tools to characterize these complicated challenges driven by nonlinearity and resonances. The progress in this project will facilitate the design of high-performance computational methods, and will provide accurate guidelines for the validity of regimes for equations. This project also involves international collaborations and training of graduate students and junior researchers in this very challenging field.

This research project is devoted to the analytical study of dynamics of compressible fluids. The project will produce further developments in four inter-related fundamental open problems. The first objective is to offer a clear characterization on the global existence and finite time blowup for compressible Euler equations with large initial data, and to find sharp density lower-bound estimate for generic large solutions. The second goal is to establish a reasonalbe justification on the isentropic approximation in compressible fluids for both inviscid and viscous fluids. The thrid objective is to investigate the validity of nonlinear dynamical Rayleigh-Taylor type instability in compressible fluids under gravity, in particular, for compressible Navier-Stokes-Fourier system. The last objective is to study the large time asymptotic behavior of compressible full Euler equations in three dimensions to justify the Darcy's law in this very complicated case, and to study the modeling and analysis for interactions between short waves and long waves in compressible fluids under the influence of magnetic field.

In the past four years, joint with his collaborators, the PI made substantial progress on these problems, gained much better understandings on these challenging problems, such as the formation of singularities, the characterization of isentropic approximations and error estimates, validity of tnonlinear dynamical Rayleigh-Taylor type instability and the effects of heat transfer, the stabilization of magnetic fields, and the mechanism of short waves and long wave interaction in aurora type phenomena.

These discoveries have been reported in published research articles to share our better understandings with peer colleagues, and to help the design of effective numerical schemes for scientific computing. The new theory and tools developed in this project supplied new and powerful tools to other researchers for their on-going research programs in related areas.

Furthermore, these results have been also reported in several international conferences and taught in mini-courses to stimulate advance researches, and to educate next generation of research forces. In the past four years, six Ph. D. students (all graduated) including 3 females involved in this research project, gained solid training to grow into independent researchers. One postdoctoral fellow made significant contributions to the project, becoming rising stars in the field.
